g.text: Anhydrous Phase B: Transmission Electron Microscope
Universit√© de Lille, CNRS, INRA, ENSCL, UMR 8207 ‚Äê UMET ‚Äê Unit√© Mat√©riaux et Transformations, Lille, France,
Department of Geology and Geophysics, Yale University, New Haven, CT, USA,
Lille, ENSCL, Universit√© d'Artois, UMR 8181 ‚Äê UCCS ‚Äê Unit√© de Catalyse et de Chimie du Solide, Lille, France,
de Montpellier, CNRS, Geosciences Montpellier, Montpellier, France
We have performed an extensive characterization by transmission electron microscopy
(including precession electron diffraction tomography and ab initio electron diffraction reÔ¨Ånement as
well as electron energy loss spectroscopy) of anhydrous phase B (Anh‚ÄêB) formed directly from olivine at
14 GPa, 1400 ¬∞C. We show that Anh‚ÄêB, which can be considered as a superstructure of olivine, exhibits
strong topotactic relationships with it. This lowers the interfacial energy between the two phases and
the energy barrier for nucleation of Anh‚ÄêB, which can form as a metastable phase. We have calculated
the elastic and seismic properties of Anh‚ÄêB. From the elastic point of view, Anh‚ÄêB appears to be more
isotropic than olivine. Anh‚ÄêB displays only a moderate seismic anisotropy quite similar to the one
Anhydrous phase B (Anh‚ÄêB) is a dense magnesium silicate with
, which is expected to form in Mg‚Äêrich or Si‚Äêdepleted regions of the mantle.
We show that due to strong crystallographic similarities with the crystal structure of olivine, it can
form directly from it as a metastable phase. We show that Anh‚ÄêB exhibits a moderate seismic anisotropy,
which makes its detection difÔ¨Åcult in the mantle.
The sequence of phase transformations of the major rock‚Äêforming minerals with increasing temperature and
pressure in the Earth's mantle is relatively well understood. The most abundant mineral in the upper mantle,
olivine, transforms to wadsleyite at 410 km (approximately 14 GPa; Katsura et al., 2004), which then
18 GPa near 1600 K; Katsura & Ito, 1989; Akaogi et al., 1989). The
second most abundant mineral, orthopyroxene, undergoes gradual transformation (completed in the pres-
sure interval 14‚Äê16 GPa) to majorite garnet through the reaction with pyrope garnet (e.g., Irifune, 1987;
Ringwood, 1991). Then ringwoodite and majorite react to forma mixture of bridgmanite and ferropericlase
(at approximately 23‚Äê24 GPa; Hirose, 2002). Through these phase transformations, the minerals change to
denser crystal structures. These changes are sometimes associated with a change in the coordination of
oxygen ions surrounding a cation, in particular silicon (Finger & Hazen, 1991).
In these two‚Äêphase transformation sequences, the (Mg+Fe)/Si ratio is between 1 and 2 (1 for orthopyroxene
and 2 for olivine). Although these two sequences explain a majority of seismological observations, the role of
some minor phases is often invoked to explain some geological observations. An important case is the
anhydrous phase B (Anh‚ÄêB), which has an unusually high (Mg+Fe)/Si ratio (2.8; Finger et al., 1991). For
example, Ganguly and Frost (2006) investigated the stability of Anh‚ÄêB and suggested that it be an explana-
tion of the so‚Äêcalled Xdiscontinuity that has been reported at 275‚Äê to 345‚Äêkmdepth in several subcontinental
and subduction zone environments. Yuan et al. (2018) extended such a study to higher pressures and pro-
posed that Anh‚ÄêB could offer an alternative interpretation of the origin of the paragenesis of olivine and peri-
clase found in some natural diamonds.
However, in both studies, the stability of Anh‚ÄêB phase relative to olivine (or wadsleyite or ringwoodite)
+ MgO was studied in a system with a very high Mg/Si ratio (=2.8). In the real Earth, (Mg+Fe)/Si
is lower (=1‚Äê2) and a more likely reaction is the formation of Anh‚ÄêB and stishovite from olivine

medium, provided the original work is
‚Ä¢ The structure of anhydrous phase B
Addad, A., Carrez, P., Cordier, P.,
Jacob, D., Karato, S.‚ÄêI., Mohiuddin, A.,
